item.title: Argon2 pbkdf setup and hardening in Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ketodiet100
item.description:
As of right now the time of writing the default LUKS Argon2id setup is 1GB (1048576 kb) for memory cost and the parallelism setting of 1-4 threads max.

These defaults were established to provide strong resistance to brute-force attacks by requiring significant computational resources, while capping parallelism to avoid excessive load on systems with limited cores. The memory cost ensures high RAM usage during key derivation, making GPU-based attacks more difficult, and the parallelism allows for multi-threaded processing up to 4 threads by default.

The iteration time is often set to around 2000 milliseconds, but memory and parallelism are the key parameters queried.

To verify these defaults you can use the cryptsetup luksDump command to inspect the current settings.

Anyway others places have suggested and discussed that if a user has sufficient RAM they should increase it more then the default (1GB) manually.

Should Kicksecure use 1/2 or 1/3 of the total memory or have an option to in Graphical installer to set this?

I think the latter since having a option for advanced installs rather then an ‚Äúopt-in‚Äù one size fits all approach. That would provide for flexibility and user by user use case when installing Kicksecure.

  • 1/2 available RAM example

--pbkdf-memory $(awk -F ' ' '/MemTotal/ {printf "%.0f\n", $2 / 2}' /proc/meminfo)

  • 1/3 available RAM example

--pbkdf-memory $(awk -F ' ' '/MemTotal/ {printf "%.0f\n", $2 / 3}' /proc/meminfo)

Typically or my understanding is that cyrptsetup will detect the max amount of threads available by the system and will use that when setting parallel defaults.
Documenting how to upgrade a Luks Kicksecure install manually to increase the Argon2 memory cost might be worth mentioning.

item.title: Messengers in wiki
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Please don‚Äôt copy/paste contents without prior discussion.

The content needs to be maintained. And that gets difficult if content is duplicated because then both versions will develop in different ways and that will get difficult ot merge.

/wiki/Software is the wrong page. /wiki/Chat would be more suitable.

And if we are doing that, the content needs to be removed from Whonix wiki, only leaving a redirection there. Or contents security (Kicksecure) vs anonymity (Whonix) like for example:

  • Send Signal Messages over Tor with Whonix ‚Ñ¢
  • Send Signal Messages with Kicksecure ‚Ñ¢

SimpleX already has a dedicated wiki page in Whonix wiki. Page it could be similarly migrated to Kicksecure wiki as it was done with Signal.

But that task is non-trivial and not suitable for first time contributors.

If considering to become a wiki editor, please start with easier improvements and see also:

Kicksecure ‚Äì 21 May 25

First-Time Source Code Contributor Policy

Guidelines and expectations for first-time contributors to ensure a smooth and respectful development experience.

item.title: Kicksecure ISO Download Broken?
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Reply for users:

Might be fixed. Please try again.

Technical information for developers:

The www subdomain (homepage; wiki) was cached with nginx proxy_pass at the server level for location /. This also included location /download. Caching huge static files such as downloads is pointless and might cause issues. This has been fixed. /download is no longer cached (and doesn‚Äôt need to be either).

item.title: Kicksecure ISO Download Broken?
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
FWIW, I‚Äôve also had download issues where the server seems to cut off my downloads at about 1 GB. I‚Äôve always downloaded Kicksecure using wget, which automatically retries the download and keeps going when this happens, so I‚Äôve never really thought of it as more than an oddity, but it sounds like for some people it can be a real problem.

Have you tried simply clicking the ‚ÄúRetry‚Äù button on the download? Sometimes the browser will be smart enough to pick up where it left off rather than starting from scratch.

item.dc:creator: @Quiksilver
item.description:
First let me ask what is your use case for wanting to mount .cache to RAM?

What is better for mounting user cache to tmpfs?

I would say the fstab and reboot method.
The other method you mentioned you would prob have to rm and recreate the directory before you syslink it

FlapJacket:

Issues related to ‚ÄúLive Mode‚Äù

Well since Live mode uses memory and you only have X amount RAM I would assume that half the amount of RAM would be used for the file system and the rest for free space. So it might reduce the RAM more?

item.title: Kicksecure ISO Download Broken?
item.dc:creator: @desi_fubu
item.description:
Hello Devs and Kicksecure Community,

I‚Äôm writing this post to bring to the attention that the Kicksecure ISO release 17.3.9.9 download appears to be broken.

This is how I got to this conclusion and the steps I took first.

First I downloaded it on Ubuntu via the Mullvad Browser and it made it to 1.0 GB then failed. So I remembered that Mullvad Browser uses their own DNS regardless if you have the Mullvad VPN or not. So I turned off their DOH settings and again it failed.

Then I freshly installed Firefox and again it fails at about 1.0 GB of the download. That made me think it was a Firefox thing, so next I tried with Brave Browser and same thing failed at the 1.0 GB mark. The ISO appears to slightly bigger then 1.0 GB. Mind you I checked my free space and despite having 173 GB of free space it failed so obliviously more then enough.

Next I tried downloading other Linux distro ISO‚Äôs and all of them fully downloaded. To test my next theory I switched/tried multiple DNS servers and again failed to download Kicksecure successfully.

Lastly I wanted to try another system to see if it was something I did so I booted up a Tails usb to download the Kicksecure ISO and again it failed despite me having more then enough RAM available (16GB).

This is really concerning cause in the past I downloaded one of the first Kicksecure ISO‚Äôs with no issue. My mind wants to go to the worst possible outcome, which I hope is not the case. Hopefully this is just a configuration issue on the server that hands out the downloads.

This needs to be looked into and investigated to see whats going on.

item.title: How many details are there in Kicksecure's fingerprint revealing to ISP the OS?
item.dc:creator: @Quiksilver
item.description:
NiksWho:

But what else (or how many) is there in traffic saying to ISP that it‚Äôs Kicksecure?

I would think this would be the standard of Networking like DHCP when connecting to a network since ISP‚Äôs (well there is a debate) indeed store all connections identifiers.

In this case the things that would make you fingerprintable are the hostname which Kicksecure sets to a generic name ‚Äúhost‚Äù and the MAC Address which currently Kicksecure doesn‚Äôt randomize.

Hostname and MAC Address are sent to a network and via DHCP request packets so these are necessarily Kicksecure but rather the identifier of you on a network.

Things that could be fingerprintable as you mentioned are outbound connections that are sent.
Others are Linux kernel headers with things like browsers but as far as the OS I would say you just look like standard Debian with Tor when you go to update.

item.title: Ephemeral Port Randomization Questions?
item.dc:creator: @Quiksilver
item.description:
Should Kicksecure stick with the default that Linux defaults to?

cat /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_local_port_range

The default range is 32768 - 60999
I‚Äôm not sure why this reasoning and is the RFC-compliant recommended range outdated?

RFC-compliant ephemeral port range (RFC 6335)

The Dynamic Ports, also known as the Private or Ephemeral Ports, from 49152-65535

Would changing the range to something Kicksecure specific increase Fingerprinting?

Should it be increased to 65535? net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range = 32768 65535
Increased entropy equals better protection against port prediction?
More ports equals less chance of port collisions under high loads?
Does changing it increase attack surface?

What are your thoughts on this since Kicksecure is also a consideration for server use?

item.title: Running portable application located on external drive
item.dc:creator: @Quiksilver
item.description:
arraybolt3:

only changes to a particular directory?

Yes, though I think you need to point config to /boot/grub/persistence.conf in the case of the Kali example (Correct me if I‚Äôm wrong):
echo -e '/home/user/.electrum source=electrum' | sudo tee -a /boot/grub/persistence.conf > /dev/null

In Kali Linux, persistence is configured by editing the persistence.conf file located at /boot/grub/persistence.conf. Persistent data is stored under /media/persistence/, which is a common location for mounting removable media.

In Tails, persistence is managed within the live environment. The configuration file persistence.conf is located at /live/persistence/TailsData_unlocked/persistence.conf. This setup allows Tails to maintain privacy by keeping persistent data within the live system structure.

Reading time: 10 mins üïë Likes: 41 ‚ù§

item.title: Messengers in wiki
item.dc:creator: @sam
item.description: Wow, it is very interesting. I read his recent articles from 2024-2025, and he also does not recommend XMPP due to weak cryptography and outdated versions of OMEMO Against XMPP+OMEMO - Dhole Moments He writes that Cwtch has not undergone any security audits. He recommends only Signal and Simplex Chat, but he acknowledges the issue of the phone number in Signal. It seems that Simplex is currently the only messenger that does not have account registration issues, encryption problems, works with Tor and the clearnet, and has powerful security features.

item.title: Messengers in wiki
item.dc:creator: @arraybolt3
item.description:
Session was given an informal security audit and did very, very poorly. The same cryptographer that did this initial investigation then wrote a followup pointing out some more problems. This same cryptographer also discovered CVEs in Matrix‚Äôs encryption, so I think they likely know what they‚Äôre doing.

I‚Äôve done quite a bit of research into SimpleX (I actually wrote some of the content that‚Äôs now in the page you linked to), and its cryptography has been security-audited with relatively positive results, so I‚Äôm pretty hopeful for it.

item.title: Messengers in wiki
item.dc:creator: @sam
item.description:
I studied all popular secure messengers and found that only Simplex provides not only high anonymity but also high protection (encrypted local storage and self-destruct passcode). This is great for Kicksecure. I think you can copy this page to the Kicksecure wiki SimpleX and add Simplex and Session Use Session Session Private Messenger Chat with Kicksecure ‚Ñ¢ to section of recommended messengers Software Recommendations

Or I can add links to the websites of these messengers in the wiki:
[https://simplex.chat/ SimpleX]
[https://getsession.org/ Session]
and maybe:
[https://docs.cwtch.im/ Cwtch]

XMPP/Jabber Client

[https://dino.im/ Dino IM]
[https://gajim.org/ Gajim]

item.title: Verified Boot
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
github.com/3mdeb/verified-boot

verified_boot_app_spec.md

7a303b906 
# Verified Boot Provisioning Wizard UEFI Application

## 1. Introduction

This document specifies the behavior and architecture of a UEFI application
designed to guide end users through the provisioning of UEFI Secure Boot.
The objective is to offer a user-controllable mechanism for managing
platform trust relationships and establishing Secure Boot infrastructure,
with a primary focus on transparency, informed consent, and usability.

Unlike traditional firmware interfaces, which expose Secure Boot as a
collection of loosely connected toggleable settings and unmanaged
certificate stores, this application presents a coherent, wizard-like
experience. Its purpose is to make the process of reviewing and enrolling
platform keys intuitive for users who are not security experts, while
ensuring strict adherence to the [UEFI Specification Version
2.7](https://uefi.org/specifications).

## 2. Application Design Overview
This file has been truncated. show original

item.title: Persistent GRUB Boot Issue with Kicksecure and Multiple SSDs
item.dc:creator: @g4a3qo6p
item.description:
I initially installed Kicksecure on an SSD in my PC and used it without any issues. After shutting down my PC and removing that SSD, I installed a different Linux distribution on another SSD, which also worked perfectly. However, when I turned off my PC and attempted to boot back into Kicksecure, it only loaded into GRUB, necessitating a reinstallation of GRUB on the Kicksecure installation. This problem recurs every time I boot into another operating system, forcing me to reinstall GRUB to use Kicksecure again.

How can I resolve this issue to avoid repeatedly reinstalling GRUB to use Kicksecure, while still being able to use other operating systems from different SSDs on my PC? Could this issue be related to my BIOS settings, and if so, what specific settings should I check or modify in the BIOS to fix it?

Disclaimer: This was anonymized with AI paraphrasing.

item.title: Avoid clearnet traffic in Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
These are just different front-ends using the same backend. (APT)

Logs / CLI output of all tools shows that.

FreshStar:

Checking for updates via Kicksecure Repository Wizard

Doesn‚Äôt exist. No connectivity.

Run it from CLI to de-mystify what it does. That goes for all tools. Check CLI output / log.

Any major action is self-documenting. These tools say what they do.

Strictly technically speaking, APT isn‚Äôt torified. It would be wrong to say ‚ÄúAPT is torified‚Äù.

What‚Äôs actually done is described here. torified updates It‚Äôs worded very carefully.

This means all default APT package manager source files are set to only update over the Tor anonymity network.

default APT package manager source files

It doesn‚Äôt include non-default, user-added APT sources.list files.

But no description is perfect and can replace looking up the actual /etc/apt/sources.list file and files in /etc/apt/sources.list.d folder.

Maybe APT, flatpak should be torified in a future version. Though, when Kicksecure Firewall gets implemented (and this feature activated), should do what you want.

But the certainty degree of avoiding clearnet leaks won‚Äôt be as good as Whonix. (Reliable IP Hiding - with Whonix - The All Tor Operating System)
